Several infectious disease specialists have suggested considering existing options such as UVGI in high-risk areas such as emergency rooms, intensive care units (ICUs), and procedure rooms. Such interventions could be cost-effective and have high yield given the scarcity of PPE.
36 Two different types of UVGI are used in healthcare settings: 1) upper room air irradiation; and 2) duct irradiation. UVGI is based on the principle of air cycling by convection between irradiated air in the upper zone (clean) and the patient care area or lower zone (dirty). Upper room air UVGI devices are placed on the ceiling or mounted on the wall. These devices have been shown to effectively reduce the transmission of airborne bacterial infections in hospitals. 37, 38, 39
